intro: Pisophaca sierrae-blancae, commonly known as the Sierra Whitebark, is a rare and endemic plant species found in the high-altitude regions of the Sierra Nevada mountains. It is a shrub-like plant characterized by its dense, white-woolly foliage that provides insulation against the harsh mountain climate. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are pollinated by wind, a common adaptation in alpine environments. Its seeds are dispersed by birds and small mammals, contributing to its limited distribution. Due to habitat loss and climate change, it is considered vulnerable and requires conservation efforts to ensure its survival.
